creator: theSTEMpedia
title: DIY RGB LED Goggles
description: This project guides you through building a pair of DIY RGB LED goggles with controllable shades that can be adjusted as per your wish. They can provide shade during the day and be customized for parties at night.
steps:
Cut out the required cardboard pieces according to the following dimensions:
    2 Pieces of 15 cm x 6 cm (Part A)
    1 piece of 9 cm x 2 cm (Part B)
    1 piece of 4 cm x 2 cm (Part C)
    1 piece of 6 cm x 2 cm (Part D)
    1 piece of 6 cm x 3 cm (Part E)
Shape one of the Part A pieces into the frame of sunglasses.
Cut holes in the second Part A piece to act as the spectacles.
Paste Part E on one side of the sunglasses frame and a small piece of straw on the other side.
Paste Part C on one side of the spectacles (Part A with holes).
Wrap Part B around the servo motor and glue the ends together.
Fix the servo horn to the servo head using the self-threading screw.
Paste two straws on both sides of the spectacles (Part A with holes). Make a small hole in Part E and paste the servo and Part E onto the spectacles.
Join the sunglasses and spectacles by inserting the small straw into the hole and the servo horn into the 6 cm x 2 cm piece of the sunglasses. Secure with hot glue.

Connect the servo wires to servo motor channel S1 on the evive, ensuring the brown wire is connected to the leftmost pin. Switch on the evive, navigate to Servo 1 in the controls menu, and turn the potentiometer knob to control the glasses.
Cut the WS2812 RGB LED strip into segments of 8, 4 and 2 LEDs.
Mount the LED strip pieces onto the front frame of the goggles.
Solder the ends of the LED strips together, connecting ground to ground, 5V to 5V, and Dout to Din.
Connect the LED strip to the evive: GND to GND, 5V to 5V, and Din to digital pin 2.
Upload the Arduino code to control the RGB LED patterns.
